subject: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.

messageBody:
I'd like to chime in on this discussion just to throw a wrench in the
works. ;)

First, I am of the notion that I don't generally want multiple failures
per test. However, there *seems* to be an assumption in this thread
that multilpe asserts per test are somehow related to each other, such
that if one fails and I fix it then the other possibly failing asserts
would be fixed at the same time. That is not always, and perhaps
generally, not the case.

Following is a simple, very contrived, example of applying a CreditMemo
to a Sale and its associated RecurringSale. This is merely an example
to show that multiple asserts within a test are not related to each
other such that fixing one would fix others, but the asserts are related
to the general action of applying a CreditMemo to an Sale.

public class SaleTest extends TestCase {
...
public void testApplyCreditMemo_whenRecurringSalesExist() {
CreditMemo cm = new
CreditMemo().newSaleAmount(-10).renewalAmount(-10);
RecurringSale renewal = RecurringSale.from(opty);
Sale opty = new
Sale().newSaleAmount(10).renewalAmount(20).addRenewal(renewal);

assertEquals(30, renewal.renewalAmount());
assertSame(Stage.NEGOTIATION, renewal.stage());

opty.applyCreditMemo(cm);

// if this fails should I assume that fixing it would also fix
the assert
// that follows concerning the renewal's CloseDate or Stage?
assertEquals(10, opty.renewalAmount());

// whether or not this fails does not guarantee that following
asserts
// would fail or pass
assertEquals(0, opty.newSaleAmount());

assertEquals(10, renewal.renewalAmount());
assertEquals(cm.invoiceDate(), renewal.closeDate());
assertSame(Stage.NOT_PURCHASED, renewal.stage());
}
...
}

public class Sale {
...
public Sale applyCreditMemo(CreditMemo aCreditMemo) {
creditMemos().add(aCreditMemo);
offsetNewSaleAmountBy(aCreditMemo.newSaleAmount());
offsetRenewalAmountBy(aCreditMemo.renewalAmount());
for(RecurringSale renewal : this.recurringSale()) {
renewal.applyCreditMemo(aCreditMemo);
}
return this;
}
...
}

public class RecurringSale extends Sale {
...
public Sale applyCreditMemo(CreditMemo aCreditMemo) {
if (parent().isFullyCancelled()) {
return close();
}
return super.applyCreditMemo(aCreditMemo);
}

private RecurringSale close() {
this.closeDate(parent().closeDate());
this.stage(Stage.NOT_PURCHASED);
return this;
}
...
}

--
Jason Rogers
